title: How to Carve Watermelon

steps.headline: Make a flat cut at the bottom of the watermelon to make it stand still.
steps.description: If you’re going to carve watermelon, you don’t want it rolling around while you’re trying to make intricate and delicate cuts. With your watermelon on a cutting board, cut a flat platform into the bottom of the rind with a long chef’s knife. Hold the watermelon with your nondominant hand, and cut once through section between ⁄4–1 inch (0.64–2.54 cm) deep at the thickest part of the rind to create a flat base for your watermelon to rest. Whether you make your cut on the short or long side of the watermelon depends on what you’re carving. Remember, the section where you make this cut will become the bottom of the watermelon. Place a towel between your cutting board and the countertop to keep your cutting board from sliding around.

steps.headline: Scoop out the watermelon’s insides if you only want the skin.
steps.description: If you’re carving watermelon for decorative purposes, you may not need the edible pieces inside. Remove the insides if you can by cutting your watermelon in half and using a large spoon to scoop them out. There’s no reason to waste perfectly good food if you don’t have to. If your project calls for chunks of watermelon to serve as part of the design, you can cut cubes out of the watermelon interior by using a chef’s knife to cut a perpendicular grid in the watermelon and scooping it out with a spoon or melon baller. Use your leftover watermelon to make a juice or simple snack. You can also freeze it and use it later.

steps.headline: Use a dry erase marker to mark cuts in your watermelon.
steps.description: If you’re carving intricate shapes into the watermelon rind, use a dry erase marker to indicate where you want to cut. The dry erase marker can easily be washed off after you’ve finished making intricate cuts.

steps.headline: Always use smooth-edge blades when cutting watermelon.
steps.description: Smooth blades are preferable when cutting or carving watermelon because they distribute pressure evenly along the edge of the blade. This will ensure that you aren’t damaging your watermelon rind when making larger cuts and will make carving much easier. Avoid serrated blades or risk damaging your watermelon.

steps.headline: Secure sections of watermelon together with toothpicks.
steps.description: If you’re creating a watermelon sculpture, you can use toothpicks to connect smaller pieces of cut-out watermelon to larger pieces. Start by inserting a toothpick into the smaller piece’s rind. With one hand on the remaining section of the toothpick and one hand on the rind that it’s connected to, guide it into the larger piece of watermelon to connect them.Tip: You can also use skewers if you have longer sections that you need to connect.

steps.headline: Create a simple watermelon bowl by cutting it in half and cleaning it.
steps.description: Cut your watermelon lengthwise in half with a chef’s knife. Then, make a smaller parallel cut roughly 4 inches (10 cm) across at the bottom of either half of your watermelon so that it rests flat on your cutting board. Use a smaller knife to carve a grid into the watermelon’s interior and use a spoon to scoop the pieces out. Use the same spoon to scrape the red, edible residue off of the rind. Wash the rind out by gently rubbing it while the rind runs under cold water to remove the residue from your watermelon bowl. You can fill the bowl with cheeses, fruit, or dip to make a fun serving dish for snacks. Since you’ll have two halves when you cut the watermelon, do this twice to make a matching pair of bowls.

steps.headline: Carve a watermelon dinosaur by cutting a menacing mouth.
steps.description: Cut a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) base lengthwise into your watermelon and stand it up. Choose a short end to be the face and use a dry erase marker to draw out an open mouth with the center section of the mouth opening 3–6 inches (7.6–15.2 cm) from lip to lip and the corners meeting on opposite sides of the melon. Cut halfway through your melon across the lines that you’ve drawn with a chef’s knife. Scoop out the mouth section with a spoon and dice the edible section into 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) triangles or squares before putting them back inside the melon. Create openings for the eyes with a melon baller by scooping out two eye sockets on opposite sides above the mouth. Use toothpicks or broken skewers to make teeth by sticking them in the section of exposed rind where you made your first cut. Use the section of rind that you removed for the mouth to make the eyebrows. Carve 2 small pieces so that they’re shaped like crescent moons. Carve parallel lines downward from the arch of each eyebrow to give the eye depth and affix them above the eye sockets with toothpicks. You can cut out small drop-shaped sections for nostrils above the center of the mouth. You can also cut out and add 2 pieces of excess rind to make them drop-shaped and attach them with toothpicks to create your nose.

steps.headline: Cut out a swan to make a beautiful centerpiece.
steps.description: Trace the outline of a swan’s neck and beak on the smoothest side of your watermelon and bring your dry erase marker around the bottom of your melon to the opposite side. Using the same line, draw triangular wings that extend outward so that you have jagged tailfeathers in the back of your outline. Carve your outline with a thin scalpel or utility knife. Remove excess layers by using a chef’s knife to cut out bigger chunks and a spoon to scoop out and smooth the interior. Use your utility knife to cut details out.Tip: Fill your swan with other pieces of melon or fruit and use it as a fun fruit bowl at a party or social event. The full outline of the swan will circle around your entire watermelon.

methods.name: Using a Stencil to Carve Messages

steps.headline: Cut a flat section across the long side of the watermelon to make a stand.
steps.description: Carving words into a watermelon rind involves making a lot of careful cuts, so you don’t want your watermelon rolling all over the place. Make a flat and even cut ⁄2–1 inch (1.3–2.5 cm) across the long bottom of the rind and use it to rest your watermelon firmly on your cutting board.

steps.headline: Print the words you want to carve and tape them to the melon.
steps.description: Type the words you want to carve in a word processing program and print them. Keep in mind, the bigger your words are, the more readable they will be. You will struggle with fitting more than 5 or 6 words on to the side of a melon, so try to keep your message short. Tape your message to the melon wherever you want to carve it with standard tape.Tip: Use a sans-serif font so that you don’t have to cut tiny details out of the edges of your letters. Use a one-word stencil if you can. That way, you can make your message incredibly legible.

steps.headline: Make incisions along the borders of each letter with a skewer.
steps.description: Poke holes along the border of each letter with the point of a skewer. Make each incision no more than 0.5 in (1.3 cm) deep. Leave no more than 0.5 in (1.3 cm) between each individual incision. Don’t lift the side of your wrist off of the watermelon as you make your incisions. This will keep your hand steady as you poke around your letters.

steps.headline: Remove your stencil and connect the dots with a scalpel or utility knife.
steps.description: Peel the tape off of your stencil and discard it. Use a sharp scalpel or utility knife to make cuts in a line between the dots that you’ve poked around your letters. Make each cut 0.5 in (1.3 cm) deep so that it matches the holes that you’ve created. This can be hard to do if you don’t have adequate light. If it’s too dark in the room, you won’t be able to see the dots that you made.

steps.headline: Scrape the letters out with a flat-edged chisel.
steps.description: Use a small chisel with a flat edge to scrape out each individual letter that you’ve carved. Dig the edge of your scalpel into any line that you’ve traced at a 45-degree angle with the chisel facing away from you. Brace the watermelon with your nondominant hand and push the chisel lightly forward. The inside of each letter will pop right out.
